repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Social Protection Special Sector
            Adjustment Loan (SP SECAL)

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is considered highly
            satisfactory, likewise, for both the Bank, and the
            Borrower's performances, who compromised on a set of
            priority programs, at a level of budgetary protection that
            would be feasible, given the Government's pressing
            fiscal constraints. Key lessons suggest: 1) that counterpart
            ownership of reform programs becomes an effective tool for
            implementation, and rapid disbursement of funds, and, that
            the Bank's willingness to support a phased program of
            reforms, ensured both budgetary protection, and a continuing
            dialogue; 2) that an effective political communication is
            paramount to social reforms strategies, and should be
            accompanied by comprehensive public information campaigns,
            provided reforming governments properly expose their reform
            rationale, which may avoid delays in implementation; 3) that
            in addition, the rationale, and extent of the Bank's
            support should also be clarified early, since the problems
            that arose from lack of understanding of the adjustment
            lending, led to confusion on the use of disbursed funds,
            whereas participation would have better been, part of the
            Brazil Rescue Package, simply as an emergency liquidity
            assistance, rather than a "Social Protection"
            loan; and, 4) that given the country's difficult
            political climate, the choice for several single-tranche
            adjustment instrument, proved successful.

5086036.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Human development

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Social Protection Special Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This loan is the first in a program of
            two sector adjustment loans (S/SECALs) in support of
            Brazil's social protection program during the expected
            period of fiscal austerity. This first loan supports the
            government's program of protected social expenditures
            developed and agreed to in October/November of 1998 that are
            targeted to the poor and to groups likely to suffer from
            increased economic insecurity during the next 12-18 months.
            Specifically, the loan funds productive agricultural
            investments to reduce poverty, improvement of the quality
            and efficiency of basic education programs in the poorest
            areas of the country, reforms in health financing, delivery
            of basic health services in the Northeast, and support for a
            key public health intervention--AIDS control. Also financed
            is analytical work, including on-going work that updates
            poverty statistics and the incidence of public social
            expenditures, reviews poverty reduction policies in the
            Northeast, reviews developmental prospects and poverty
            issues in Rio de Janeiro, produces a dialogue on labor
            issues, and provides discussions on a range of educational
            issues such as quality, enrollments, institutional
            strengthening, and funding mechanisms.
